Against this backdrop, Kremlin will less likely reduce its defense budget since the Russian arms industry employs around two million workers, whose support for the Kremlin regime is essential. Russia has spent 903 billion roubles on defense for the first three months of this year according to the Ministry of Finance [1]. This represents a year-on-year increase on Q1 2018 of 13%. It is worth noting that defense is a sub-category within military expenditure as I have explained previously [2]. This notwithstanding, what does a 13% increase tell us about possible military spending in 2019?  In 2018, Russia spent 3.85 trillion roubles on military spending [3]. If that rose by 13% this year it would equal 4.3 trillion. According to the latest IMF World Economic Outlook, Russian GDP will be 108 trillion in 2019, meaning military spending of 4.3 equals to just under 4%.   This is very simple analysis is meant to simply say: what does existing data tell us about the answer to the question. It bears noting that there are more important factors that will determine the eventual outcome. As I've written before, Russia's announced budgets suggest spending well under 4.4% [2], [5], [6]. Furthermore, Russia's domestic economic problems persist and require increasing attention. Putin's approval rating has continued to suffer [8] raising questions about how he may want to redirect national spending to raise his appeal to the people. Between 1992 and 2018 (a 26-year span), Russian military spending was an average of 3.91% per GDP. The percentage decreased by 23% between 2016 and 2017 and by 5% between 2017 and 2018. This shows two trends: first, military spending is rarely above 4.4% of GDP and it has been decreasing since 2016. Russian military spending has only been equal or above 4.4% of GDP four times in that time period and the spending drop between 2016 and 2017 is the largest since the period between 1997 and 1998, when military spending as a percentage of GDP decreased by 32.5%. The largest increases were 25.8% between 2008 and 2009, 19.5% between 2014 and 2015, and 14.8% between 1998 and 1999 while the majority of increases were between 2 and 9% of GDP. An increase to 4.4% of GDP from the current level of 3.9% would be an overall increase of 12.8, which has not happened during this time period: the closest was that 14.8% increase between 1998 and 1999. Therefore, while there is a chance that Russian military spending as a percentage of GDP will be 4.4% or larger, that is very unlikely.

Ceteris Paribus, Russian defense spending as a share of GDP will continue to decline into 2019.  Russia faces serious domestic economic concerns (i.e. degraded infrastructure, over reliance on energy exports, rising poverty) that will curb its ability to devote more resources to its military.  This, however, does not necessarily suggest the long term degradation of Russia military power.  Russia's military relies on conscripts, which means that outside of the money needed to provide initial training, it does not necessarily need to devote as much money to funding year round readiness, or invest as heavily in training like its Western competitors with more professional armed services.  Instead, it devotes more of its defense budget to R&D, procurement, and modernization.  While all of these initiatives have significant up front expenses, their true costs can be spread out over a longer time horizon.  This helps Russia keep its military spending low.  Finally, Russia is undoubtedly itching to find a way to withdraw its military forces from Syria.  Although the intervention has been hugely successful for Putin, and it has considerably raised his domestic and international standing, he knows that once events "go South" (i.e. Russian death toll increases in country) these gains will erode.  Therefore, Putin will most likely seek a way to extricate Russia/himself from a hard military presence in Syria, thereby further decreasing Russian military spending in 2019.

Using SIPRI's excel spreadsheet of all of Russia's military expenditures as a percentage of GDP, I created a box-and-whisker plot to show a range of all percentages since 1988. First, what I found was that 2016 was an outlier year. It was the only percentage to break 5% in this period. Second, the upper limit was 4.9% (excluding the 2016, the outlier, of course) with a lower limit of 3.0%. The median was 3.9%, while the mean was 4.0%, and the upper quartile was 4.3%, which goes to show how typically low the budget is. In all fairness, it is important to note that from 2014 to 2017 (the most recent data available) the expenditure percentage was higher than the mean, but only 2015 and 2016 broke even a 4.4% expenditure. As a result of all of this, I am very doubtful of another outlier year, and expect 2019 to be less than 4.9%. Given that the budget has only broken 4.4% five times in the 26 years we have data for, I am going with 75% "less than 4.4%" and 25% "4.4% to 4.9%", which is percentage that Russia has exceeded 4.4% in the past, plus a 5% bump due to ongoing conflicts that Russia is involved in. Source:https://www.sipri.org/sites/default/files/SIPRI-Milex-data-1949-2017.xlsx

Russia's federal budget for 2017-2019, suggests a spending of 2.8 trillion roubles on "national defense" [1]. It is worth noting, however, that SIPR's definition of "military spending" is more expansive than the federal definition for "national defense", with SIPRI numbers consistently higher than "national defense" figures with the difference in the order of hundreds of billions of roubles. For example, SIPRI's definition includes spending for paramilitary forces and military pension payments  [2], which are not covered by the federal government definition of "national defense". This paper [3, pages 17 and 23] provides a disambiguation of the terms. To estimate 2019 "military spending" I took "national defense" expenditure budgeted for 2019 (2.8 trillion roubles) and added a residual accounting for additional expenditures not counted under "national defense". This residual was estimated as the average difference between "national defense" spending and SIPRI military spending in 2016 and 2017. This leads to an estimate of 3.77 trillion roubles in 2019.  Russia's GDP (expressed in current roubles, consistent with SIPRI's numbers) is projected to be 106 trillion roubles in 2019 by the IMF (projection as of October 2018) [4] This suggests military spending equal to 3.6% of GDP. It is important to account for potential budgetary adjustments as budgets are revised every year. For example, Russia increased its 2018 budget by 8% [5] compared to the 2017-2019 budget I quoted. An impetus for further increases in military spending could, for example, come from the recent rise in the oil price. The aforementioned 2017-2019 budget is based on a price of $40. The current price is above $80. Price levels in 2019 are highly uncertain but it's very likely that the price will stay far above $40. The EIA assumes the oil price will stay near its current levels in 2019 [6]. Still, there might be reasons for spending to go down rather than up. Russia may want to spend more of its budget domestically, particularly given that Putin's popularity has fallen as indicated by polls by two different organizations, [7], partially in the wake of a deeply unpopular rise in the retirement ages. Recent announcements by Putin do point toward a lowering of military spending in 2018 and 2019 [8]. While the 2018 budget was revised by 8%, I assume that 95% of the variation in military spending compared to the 2017-2019 budget will be within 25% (particularly as this term includes uncertainty in "national defense" spending and the residual discussed above). A 25% upward revision to the 2019 figure estimated above would result in military spending equal to 4.7 trillion, or 4.5% of IMF's GDP estimate. It bears mentioning that GDP and military spending adjustments are not independent. Instead, there is probably some correlation. This correlation reduces the variability that we can expect from military spending expressed as a % of GDP, leading me to lower the 4.9%>X>4.4% chances slightly (from ~5% to 3%). Finally, I account for "unknown unknowns" by raising the probability of 4.9%>X>4.4% by 6 % points. Levels at or above 4.9% seem very unlikely from a historical standpoint. Spending as a % of GDP has been at 4.9% or above only 4 times out of the last 26 years, with an average around 4% (on the basis of SIPRI data). Pondering which base rate to use. Some simple averages:
4.0% for 1992-2017 (whole dataset)
4.1% for 2008-2017 (period since intervention in Georgia)
4.7% for 2014-2017 (period since intervention in Ukraine)
4.9% for 2015-2017 (period since intervention in Syria) Interesting that the years immediately following the Georgia, Ukraine and Syria interventions (2009, 2015 and 2016 respectively) saw the largest year-on-year jumps in the spend measure. None of these increases were sustained - in all cases, the spend measure dropped significantly within 1 or 2 years of the jump.  This plausibly suggests that new military engagements have a short-term impact on military spend as a % of GDP, but says nothing about longer-term trends. The period 2014-2017 contains 2 separate "post-intervention years" (and has only a very small number of data points) so I have gone with the "post-Georgia" 2008-2017 period base rate of 4.1%.

I assign a more than even percent chance that the Russian Federation will increase its military spending budget in terms of GDP from the previous level of 4.3% to anywhere between the 4.4-4.9% range. My reasoning is based on the positive trend in the crude oil price that has continued since 2016, increased engagement in the African continent leading to increased exports, and the gradual reduction of Russian presence in Syria following the end of major operations against ISIS.

The highest recorded military expenditure as a percentage of GDP conducted by the Russian Federation was 5.5% in 2016. Russia's 2019 military expenditures will focus on achieving near-parity to U.S. and Chinese capabilities in areas such as hypersonics. This will be balanced against Russia's strategic use of cyber and political warfare to achieve its desired aims. There has been expressed the desire to thaw U.S.-Russia relations and attempts to strengthen the Sino-Russian defense cooperation. Still, the leaders of the aforementioned nations view the world through a realist lens and will ultimately operate consistent with the principles of relative gains. The security dilemma that NATO poses for the Russian Federation will potentially drive GDP percentage expenditures for military over the 5% threshold.

Looking at both historical trends and the current environment, it can be seen that 2015 and 2016 were outliers for Russia in terms of military expenditure. They were typically allocating less than 4.4.% with a growth of around .3% per year. With the current economic situation within Russia and the lack of a direct conflict high intensity that would necessitate an outlier year (such as 2016) it can be expected that it would follow a similar trend. Having returned to the expected 4.2% in 2017, if this trend is followed than it would put it between 4.4 and 4.9. Slight growth would mean that it would remain under 4.4%, however with recent activity in Syria and the need to maintain a presence there it is likely that it will experience a healthy level of growth (relative to historical trends). Pressure by the United States in NATO allies to hit a benchmark goal in military expenditure may encourage Russia as well, as they look to embarrass NATO countries or simply to increase intimidation.

This is a numerator - denominator problem, and more specifically, an elasticity of the numerator to the denominator problem. Military spending growth lags government revenue growth, and government revenue growth lags oil price growth. Thus, I expect those speaking of oil price movements in late 2018 determining 2019 defense spending are likely going to overestimate the impact of the oil price moves. Second, the dollar (or ruble) amount of spending should really be seen as a real life set of assets and people being mobilized. Defense % of GDP is not a dial to turn based on geopolitical events. The amount of spending is not very easy to change. Thus, I used the average of the last three years as a base rate (Putin would have been of a different mind before 2015). It quickly showed that 2016 was an abnormal year. So I ignored 2016 and assumed the previous year ruble amount (not % GDP) plus some growth on the 2017 ruble GDP, using the latest assumed GDP growth rate of 1.9% (August).

Using Russia’s average military spending as a percentage of GDP since 1992 (based on SIPRI estimates)—4.0%—as a baseline, and considering last year’s drop in spending (both as a percentage of GDP and in absolute terms) corresponding with ongoing economic problems and the imposition of more international sanctions over the last few months, it seems likely that the trend will remain similar over the next year (https://money.cnn.com/2018/05/02/news/russia-defense-spending-plunge/index.html). Although, oil prices could mitigate that somewhat (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-09-27/oil-s-leap-toward-100-is-softening-the-blow-of-russia-sanctions).

Although the bellicose rhetoric coming out of Russia would suggest otherwise, in reality Russia's military spending has declined in 2017 as compared to 2016, and seems to be projected to drop again this year (2018).  This does not mean Russia does not spend a lot of money as per its GDP, actually more than the United States.  However, the economic woes within the Russian economy are real and have an impact even on their military expenditures.  Dropping almost 20% from 2016 over 2017, I project that Russia's military spending as percentage of GDP is likely to drop within 4.4-4.9% for 2019.

Russia has been increasing efforts in Syria as well as in other global arenas. They are also consistently attempting to increase their global image, and are known to place a large emphasis on military as a source of power. I feel that for this reason they will slightly increase their military spending. I do not feel that they will drastically increase it, as they have domestic needs to attend to as well.

SIPRI take account of all military-related expenditure including on pensions & paramilitary forces (any force that can be transferred to or serves the function of a military unit, so e.g. Rosgvardiya units fall under this, and certain FSB units, but I don't think the police do). This is higher than the often-reported expenditure per the Russian budget headings, which is why despite widely reported cuts (e.g. figs here https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-12-14/russia-s-military-is-leaner-but-meaner) the actual effect on SIPRI reported expenditure may not be so sharp.  Constant post-2011 upwards trend according to SIPRI with incremental jumps c. 0.3% (although marginally quicker since RUB devaluation in 14/15). So if current patterns hold 2019 will fall between 6.5% GDP and 5.9% of GDP (0.4 -0.2pa).   However, I don’t expect the pattern to hold. Russia is well above post-CW averages for expenditure and also above global averages – inc. above US & China. Reversion to mean is likely to take effect as current rate seems unsustainable. Budget pressures & current forecasts suggest cuts. 2016 expenditure seems to include an early debt wipe out, so that would also be artificially high if so – in fact, it probably masks underlying cuts - see Mark Galeotti for the ECFR here: https://www.ecfr.eu/article/commentary_the_truth_about_russias_defence_budget_7255
n.b the percentages don’t match SIPRI due to different definitions of MilEx.  Military expenditure doubles with a domestic political element – jobs. As Galeotti points out cities like Nizhny Tagil are Putin’s heartland, and Russia also earns from military exports. There is every incentive not to make swingeing cuts if avoidable. If OPEC Vienna agreement co-operation holds & oil stays at its higher recent rates GDP should increase more quickly (current EIU forecasts are for raises of 1.9% in 2018) which would potentially mean that the percentage share could fall while holding absolute rates. Prices are currently above $40/bbl, which is above MOF Budget policy assumptions (according to a March 2017 paper by Julian Cooper at Birmingham University CREES, available from researchgate.net) so that might help soften the blow to the defence budget.  As long as the Syrians don't need urgent support again and nothing else immediately develops, domestic non-military expenditure probably needs to be prioritised. Therefore, I am betting that the rates will ease back under 5%, especially if GDP returns to growth. Could go further than that. Still, all risky with a huge number of variables and differing definitions.

This question is a ratio question: two estimates are made. First, will Russia increase/decrease its military expenditure. Second, what would be Russian GDP for 2019.  If Mr. Putin continues his aggressive policy, he may incur extra costs: to pay for foreign expenditure such as troops in Syria, funding Ukraine insurgency. Need to pay personnel, to replace equipments, etc. 
Russia also needs to modernize their weapons too. Recent missile strike in Syria by USA-Britain-France shows that Russia has no shield. Of course, they may not equip Bashar Al Assad with the latest technology, but I would think they would use the opportunity to test out their equipment effectiveness, instead of wait for the real war on Russian soil to find out. The USA has confidence of their missile defense system by helping Israel develop its Iron Dome Missile Defense system. (Caveat, the Iranian missiles are not USA smart missiles, so Iron Dome may not as effective against Tomahawk missiles). My point is that it is likely Russia and China will have to accelerate their missile defense research.  Russian economy isn't in very good shape. By picking up fight with USA over Syria, by overly active with cyber warfare, by poisoning people on UK soil, Russia becomes more and more isolated. Although oil price is coming back up, throwing a lifeline to Russian budget, the fact that USA has lifted its ban on exporting oil and gas, and has become energy independent, making Western Europe less dependent on Russian oil and gas. Current sanction on Rusal (aluminum company), may hit Russia economy, due to its dependency on natural resource export. On the other hand, global economy seems to improve, and therefore may help increase Russian GDP. In light of the above, waiting for the 2017 reading, I would favor 5.5% to 6.0% bin, with more bias toward 6% than less than 4.4%.
